Q15_10_TEXT: Please, no more online platforms where all available scientific information is available. Greater participation in ARCCA or similar groups with a focus on the newest and latest relevant reports is much more helpful (see some of the ARCCA webinars etc...). In my experience, planners are highly educated and know how to interpret the science. Having the most up-to-date and relevant science culled and presented is what's needed.

Q20_13_TEXT: On the Coastal side of the County, we are dealing with the Coastal Commission who takes a heavy-handed regulatory approach to addressing SLR. They offer no flexibility, limit local government control, and thereby limit creative approaches. The CCC is an example of how not to address SLR with a new regional authority or an existing authority with expanded jurisdiction. So far, BCDC's approach is far superior and a great example of leadership that provides opportunities for real stakeholder participation.

Q17_13_TEXT: Vulnerable areas are generaaly limited in coverage and extent, but contain a variety of the sectors liste (transporation, water, wastewater, housing, commercial and other built development) making adaptation more complex. Wetlands are directly a function of sea level, so the gradient of impact will begin immediately. Home values in affected areas will feel the impact of anticipated damamge and at some point begin to act like a wasting asset.

Q15_10_TEXT: I do not think that the scientific information is the main challenge- it is a whole host of other barriers- financing and funding, governance and policy, ability to engage the community and private industry, legal and CEQA barriers, translation of how to make decisions in uncertain environments. Q32: Sea level rise projections,Other (please explain in the text box)
Q32_13_revision: Sea level rise projections
Q32_13_TEXT: We propose a dike approximately under the Bay Bridge.  Perhaps a mile wide.  Built to keep rising as sea level rises even to 60 meters.  Initially using tidal power to flush the South Bay and restore its oyster, herring, and other fisheries to 1900's levels.  Pump down (pause at low tide) ahead of rain storms to prevent rain storm flooding all around the South Bay.  The dike and complete fisheries restoration is less expensive than increased flood insurance, and therefore can be voluntarily as "lower cost flood insurance."  Ask for our Bay Area Challenge entry.  Way better long-term adaptation than Bay Area Challenge winners.
Q15: Other (please explain in the text box)
Q15_10_TEXT: Start seriously planning projects that can keep up with the worst predictions of sea level rise.  South San Francisco Bay is a unique opportunity.  You can get the rest of the Bay complaining they are not within its protection.  The dike is easily funded as an alternative to flood insurance.  The food productivity of restoring the old fisheries helps pay for the structure.  The dike creates more real estate to pay for itself.
Q16: They are starting to be felt right now
Q18: Other (please explain)
Q18_15_TEXT: Establish a South Bay regional authority to build the dike.  The economics work very well for the South Bay by itself.  The South Bay has the most urgency combined with a containable amount of rain flood water.  This action then galvanizes other areas around the Bay.
Q19: Carrying out research projects jointly with other organizations,Preparing grant/funding proposals jointly with other organizations,Other (please specify)
Q19_15_TEXT: Ask for our Bay Area Challenge entry
Q20: Other (please explain)
Q20_13_TEXT: Funded by ARPA-E's MARINER project to work the fisheries restoration angle big-time.
Q25_9_TEXT: They think long-term, how the system can be expanded to live where the future jobs are.  The future of food, energy, and sustained biodiversity is in the oceans.
Q41_1: Any with the long-term perspective to run with the dike.  We have moved to global food, energy, and ocean restoration.

Q32: Other (please explain in the text box)
Q32_13_TEXT: My company finances (through PACE) climate mitigation measures (i.e. energy efficiency and renewable energy) on privately-owned buildings (mostly owner-occupied single family residences).  We also are legally allowed to finance water conservation and seismic retrofit measures.  In theory we could do more work that more directly impacts sea level rise if the CA Legislature were to make sea level rise mitigation measures a legally financeable measure on private properties.
Q15: Other (please explain in the text box)
Q15_10_TEXT: The best available science may be ignored if there is no way to pay for the solution to which the science points.  So (as stated above), in theory we could do more work that more directly impacts sea level rise if the CA Legislature were to make sea level rise mitigation measures a legally financeable measure on private properties.

Q18_15_TEXT: We also need to create a roadmap for the development of; a bay wide local, sub regional, and regional adaptation strategies that is scalable and implementable at various timelines and changing sea level rises.
Q18_16_TEXT: We have options and actions that we need to perform at every level, but before we try to respond for example at a local level to build a coastal project, we need to know what the maximum threshold of respond for local governments should be. There are many decisions that need to be discussed and agreed upon at sub-regional and regional level and local government should not make those decisions for the rest of the Bay. Unfortunately we havent started that conversation in a constructive way due to multitude of short sided interests.
